> From: Jim Dixon [mailto:jdd@...]
> 
> I wrote, quoting the JUnit W=
eb site:
> 
> > "Tests need to run against the background of a known 
> > s=
et of objects. This set of objects is called a test 
> > fixture."

I haven=
't said anything in this thread, but, as a former QA professional, I always=
 look to the QA gods, G. Myers, B. Beizer or R. Binder for definitions rela=
ted to testing.  Developers who haven't read some of the QA classic literat=
ure often sound like dilletantes when they try to speak with authority abou=
t testing concepts and terms.  You never find universal agreement on defini=
tions, but you can at least broaden the investigation beyond what Beck or G=
amma said once upon a time.  This comment is about the thread in general, n=
ot directed specifically at Jim's comment.
 
> For the last several months =
I have been working on software that
> instruments Java classes.  It does t=
his by adding bytecode to 
> the compiled class as it is being loaded.  The=
 software that does
> this is tested using JUnit.  The class that is delive=
red by the 
> classloader is in fact the main "object" of the test fixture.=
  
> This class is related to the Java class, the file with the 
> .class e=
xtension, but it is not the same.  Among other
> things, it is much larger =
:-(
[snip]
> In other words, fixtures can include classes, although they 
>=
 almost always consist only of objects.

I think you're equivocating on the=
 word 'class' here.  Classes are always dealt programmatically in Java via =
the java.lang.Class object, or, if you're manipulating the constituent bina=
ry data, via an InputStream or some other object.  I think you were right b=
efore, in the general sense: Java deals with objects except for the primiti=
ve types.

Scott Stirling
Framingham, MA
